metadata.title: Reduction in urban atmospheric CO 2 enhancement in seoul, South Korea, resulting from social distancing policies during the COVID-19 pandemic

A two-point calibration was performed for the SNUCO2M once every two weeks using 109 zero gas (0 ppm) and two span gases of CO2 (400 and 1000 ppm). The maximum error range 110 of SNUCO2M is 0.71% from the observed value, indicating that it is suitable for measuring a 111 wide range of urban CO2 concentrations (Park et al., 2020b) .

SNUCO2M was installed at several sites around the Seoul Capital Area. In this study, two 113 sites from the SNUCO2M network were used. One site was located on the roof of the Yongsan operating since July 2019. The SNUCO2M at NST is located horizontally near the YSB site 120 (i.e., 3.5 km apart), but the inlet was installed at a much higher altitude (420 m asl). A (G2131, Picarro Inc., Santa Clara, CA, USA) was installed at the site, and the CO2 analyzer 128 had a precision of < 200 ppb and was calibrated regularly using the same method as the 129 SNUCO2M. Hourly averaged CO2 concentration data were used in this study after removing 130 the outlying CO2 concentration data at the three sites, caused by malfunction of the instrument and calibration.

The observed CO2 concentration data were analyzed using two methods (Park et al., 2020b) 133 to quantify urban CO2 enhancement (△CO2 = CO2 Urban − CO2 Background ), representing the urban 134 contribution of atmospheric CO2 concentration from Seoul. In brief, the first method 135 considered the difference in vertical CO2 concentrations in the Seoul Capital Area. By 136 comparing the CO2 concentrations measured at YSB and NST, located adjacent to each other 137 but at different altitudes, the CO2 enhancement (△CO2) could be quantified (i.e., a local effect).

The second method uses the horizontal difference in CO2 concentration, which compares 146 the CO2 concentration at Seoul with that in the outer background area. We quantified △CO2 by 147 comparing the CO2 concentrations between YSB and GWA (△CO2 2 = CO2 YSB − CO2 GWA ).

As shown in Table 1 it was difficult to evaluate the effect of implemented policies in real-time using inventory data 296 that accounted for energy use in each building, since inventory data for the present year are 297 typically not available until two to three years later (Seoul Metropolitan Government, 2017) .

In contrast, the urban CO2 observation data used in this study made it possible to verify the 299 effects of policy-induced atmospheric CO2 concentration reduction in real-time. Therefore, to 300 develop and evaluate policies for future CO2 emissions reduction, it is suggested that these 301 urban CO2 ground observations should be extended.

Taking advantage of these real-time CO2 observations, this study confirmed that the phase-303 by-phase social distancing policies implemented in Seoul due to the COVID-19 pandemic led 304 to a reduction in human activity and even led to a reduction in the atmospheric CO2 305 concentration. This suggests that if effective policies that can reduce CO2 emissions from 306 human activity are developed and implemented in cities around the world in the future, they 307 will prevent the rapid rise in global CO2 concentrations and effectively mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 virus has caused tremendous socioeconomic damage; however, it has provided 309 a positive outlook regarding the potential for future climate change and greenhouse gas 310 reduction, demonstrating the important role of effective policies and cities in managing 311 greenhouse gas levels. using two different methods during the pre-COVID-19, Level 1, and Level 2.5 periods.

The mean CO2 concentration in YSB during this period is 442.99 ppm, which 199 is 11.00 and 13.34 ppm higher than that of NST (432.00 ppm) and GWA (429.65 ppm),200 respectively. In general, the three observation sites well represent variations in urban and local 201 background CO2 concentrations in downtown Seoul. In addition, the average CO2 202 concentration over the three stations (e.g., 434.88 ppm) is higher than that from Mauna Loa by 203 22.23 ppm obtained from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration 204 (https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/trends/data.html; Thoning et al., 1989). 205 Using the observed CO2 concentration data, urban enhancement in Seoul was quantified 206 in two ways. Fig. 2a shows a box plot of △CO2 1 for each period quantified using method 1, 207 which considers the difference in vertical CO2 concentration. The average △CO2 1 during the 208 pre-COVID-19 period is 22.56 ppm but decreases to 14.23 ppm during the Level 1 period and 209 10.99 ppm during the Level 2.5 period (Table 2). The 95 th percentile of △CO2 1 , a proxy for 210 high CO2 concentration emissions in Seoul, decreased more significantly from 59.04 ppm 211 during the pre-COVID-19 period to 40.94 and 36.15 ppm during Level 1 and Level 2.5 periods, 212 respectively. We calculated the urban contribution for each period (urban contribution = △CO2 213 / CO2 concentration × 100; Fig. 2b) to compare the percentage of △CO2 1 accounting for 214 atmospheric CO2 concentrations in Seoul. The degree to which the CO2 concentration due to 215 urban emissions affected the atmospheric CO2 concentration for each period was 4.81%, on 216 average, during the pre-COVID-19 period but decreased to 3.07% and 2.46% during the Level 217 1 and Level 2.5 periods, respectively. Compared with the pre-COVID-19 period, Seoul's urban 218 contribution was reduced by half, and Seoul's CO2 concentration showed a decreasing tendency 219 from 451.76 ppm during the pre-COVID-19 period to 451.38 and 434.54 ppm during the Level 220 1 and Level 2.5 periods, respectively. In contrast, background CO2 concentration increased although the urban CO2 concentration of Seoul reduced due to rapid decrease in CO2 emissions 267 caused by the social distancing policies. In other words, CO2 concentration in cities that are 268 known to generate most of the world's CO2 emissions can be effectively reduced by policies 269 that curb human activity (Duren and Miller, 2012; Schwandner et al., 2017). In addition, △CO2 270 and the urban contribution of Seoul over the Level 2.5 period showed a greater reduction than 271 that of the Level 1 period. Since Level 2.5 was implemented for only two weeks, the reduction 272 in CO2 concentration would have been more noticeable if the implementation period was longer. 273 This indicates that the intensity of the policies implemented within the city can greatly affect 274 the reduction in CO2 emissions. 275 The reduction of atmospheric CO2 concentration in urban areas can be considered a 276 compound result of changes in local weather conditions and direct emission from the city 277 (Xueref-Remy, 2018; Park et al., 2020a). Therefore, we analyzed the correlation between urban 278 CO2 enhancement and meteorological parameters (i.e., temperature, precipitation, wind 279 direction, and wind speed) during the research period to examine the impact of meteorological 280parameters on urban CO2 enhancement. We found that there was no statistically significant 281 correlation between urban CO2 enhancement and temperature and precipitation. In addition, 282 the urban CO2 enhancement did not significantly vary with the direction of the wind at the YSB 283 site. In contrast, CO2 enhancement showed a distinct exponential relationship with wind speed; 284 however, the average wind speed in Seoul was not significantly different during the pre-285 COVID-19, Level 1, and Level 2.5 periods. This demonstrates that the decrease in atmospheric 286 CO2 concentration in Seoul during the COVID-19 pandemic results from changes in direct CO2 287 emissions from Seoul due to social distancing policies.288The reduction in CO2 emissions due to COVID-19 social distancing policies was verified using traffic volume, which accounts for the largest portion of the emission sources in Seoul290 and floating population, presumed to represent human activity (Seoul Metropolitan 291 Government, 2017). The results show that the traffic volume and floating population around 292 the YSB site decreased by 10.73% and 12.55% during the Level 1 period and by 43.25% and 293 14.11% during the Level 2.5 period, respectively.
